description: The Microsoft Technology Associate (MTA) validates building-block technology concepts and helps students explore, discover and pursue successful careers in Information Technology (IT) in an exciting and rewarding way! As the first step in the Microsoft Technology Certification Series, this new, entry-level certification provides students with confidence, credibility, and differentiation while focusing on basic terminology, and concepts like CIA Triad, which is a set of core security principles that can provide as the foundation for security. To gain an MTA certification, you must pass only one MTA exam.
descriptionMD: The Microsoft Technology Associate (MTA) validates building-block technology concepts and helps students explore, discover and pursue successful careers in Information Technology (IT) in an exciting and rewarding way! As the first step in the Microsoft Technology Certification Series, this new, entry-level certification provides students with confidence, credibility, and differentiation while focusing on basic terminology, and concepts like CIA Triad, which is a set of core security principles that can provide as the foundation for security. To gain an MTA certification, you must pass only one MTA exam.
name: MTA - Security Fundamentals  - 98-367 (2017)
subtitle: Security Fundamentals

episodes.description: In this episode, Peter and Mike dive into MTA security fundamentals. They starting with defining key terms that will be used throughout the course like the CIA triad and risk management.
episodes.title: Core Security Principles

episodes.description: In this part two, Peter and Mike pick up where they left off on security principles. They cover topics like the principle of least privilege, social engineering, and attack surface analysis.
episodes.title: Core Security Principles Part 2

episodes.description: Before you consider your cyber security, it is important to understand the importance of your physical security risks. Peter and Mike explain the levels of physical security like the external perimeter, internal perimeter, and secure areas before getting into the physical security related to your computers themselves.
episodes.title: Physical Security

episodes.description: In this episode, Peter and Mike detail the inherent risks that come with browsing the internet. They also show the various tools available within Internet Explorer to combat them.
episodes.title: Internet Security

episodes.description: There is more than one way to secure your wireless network. Mike and Peter look at the different security types available and take you step by step through each of them.
episodes.title: Wireless Security

episodes.description: In this part two, Peter and Mike go beyond wireless keys to cover topics like SSID configuration and MAC filtering. They show hands on how to set up each of these.
episodes.title: Wireless Security Part 2

episodes.description: Passwords are just one way to authenticate users on your network. In this episode, Peter and Mike outline the different pieces that make up multifactor authentication while discussing the pros and cons of each.
episodes.title: User Authentication

episodes.description: In this continuation, Peter and Mike dig deeper into authentication options like biometrics. They also look at the "Run as" tool as a way to make changes within certain programs in Windows.
episodes.title: User Authentication Part 2

episodes.description: Mike and Zach discuss how to define permissions, permissions over object, file systems, file system permissions, basic permissions & advanced permissions, inherited permissions, explicit permissions, and appropriate permission choices.
episodes.title: Permissions

episodes.description: Mike and Zach continue the discussion of explicit vs. inherited permissions, hierarchy of precedence, how to enable & disable inheritance, what are NTFS permissions, and more.
episodes.title: Permissions Part 2

episodes.description: Mike and Zach conclude the discussion of permissions, what is Full Control, administrators have Take Ownership permissions, behavior when moving or copying files within the same disk or other disks, copying within & without volumes, sharing permissions, using the UNC path, mapped drives, NTFS permissions, what is the most restrictive permissions, is Full Control best, administrative permissions known as 'Hidden,' what ADMIN$ and IPC$ mean, and print permissions.
episodes.title: Permissions Part 3

episodes.description: Mike and Zach discuss what a registry is, what registry permissions are, the practicality of using the registry to make permissions changes, how to use Regedit, the various keys, what are Hives, key value, file types, registry values, and exporting registry.
episodes.title: Registry Permissions

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike dive into the world of Active Directory. They look at the benefits of Active Directory as well as discussing NTLM, Kerberos, SSO, domain controllers and multi-master replication.
episodes.title: Active Directory Permissions

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike continue their dive into the world of Active Directory. They discuss concepts like organizational units, local vs. domain users accounts and computer accounts.
episodes.title: Active Directory Permissions Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike continue their dive into the world of Active Directory. They discuss groups, group types, group scopes as well as group strategies, built-in groups and group delegation.
episodes.title: Active Directory Permissions Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Zach go over password fundamentals such as regulating how users actually create and use passwords, password complexity, password history, enforcing group policies, and domain policies override local policies.
episodes.title: Password Policies

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Zach conclude the discussion on password policies discussing account lockout, common attack methods such as Brute Force, password reset procedures, protect domain user account passwords, reverse encryption, and hashing passwords.
episodes.title: Password Policies Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike tackle the concepts surrounding audit policies. They look at the different types of auditing and different objects that can be audited as well as demonstrating how to enable auditing.
episodes.title: Audit Policies

episodes.description: Mike and Zach discuss what encryption algorithms are, what cypher text is, the difference between Symmetric-Asymmetric algorithms, private keys, public keys, how to use the keys & best application, and hashing.
episodes.title: Encryption

episodes.description: Mike and Zach conclude the discussion of encryption covering what encryptions are, how they are used, file systems, NTFS, what EFS is, what TPM is, what Bitlocker is, how to use Bitlocker, other software based encryption, mail encryption, VPN, certificate properties, certificate services, PKI/certificate services, what token devices are, and lock down devices.
episodes.title: Encryption Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike discuss various common types of malware that can be present in modern information systems. They talk about viruses, worms, trojan horses, ransomware, rootkits and more.
episodes.title: Malware

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike take a look at firewalls. They discuss the different types of firewalls like packet filtering, circuit filtering, application-level firewalls and multi-level firewalls as well as discussing the differences between these firewall types.
episodes.title: Dedicated Firewalls

episodes.description: Mike and Zach discuss understanding network isolation, LAN, using multiple LANS, what a Virtual Lan (VLAN) is, assigning hosts to VLANS, how a router can help, the difference between software and hardware routers, and how all this works together in Network Isolation.
episodes.title: Network Isolation

episodes.description: Mike and Zach cover what what Routing Protocols are, different types of protocols, what Count To Infinity means, Link State, what a Honey Pot is, how to use a Honey Pot, Perimeter Networks, DMZ, Inside DMZ, what NAT is, and the difference between Static NAT & Dynamic NAT.
episodes.title: Network Isolation Part 2

episodes.description: Mike and Zach conclude the discussion of Network Isolation by covering IPsec, IPsec Protocols, what AH is, what ESP is, Internet Key Exchange (IKE), what protocols must be used foe different applications, encapsulating data, what a Tunnel, how to use a Tunnel, SSL, TLS, and server & domain isolation.
episodes.title: Network Isolation Part 3

episodes.description: Mike and Zach cover what Protocol Security means, what Tunneling is, generic routing encapsulation, point to point tunneling protocol, routing traffic across an insecure network, DNS, DNSsec, public key encryption, protocol spoofing, ARP spoofing, DNS spoofing, IP address spoofing, network sniffing, IPsec, and common attack methods.
episodes.title: Protocol Security

episodes.description: Mike and Zach talk about what client protection is, how we can better insure client protection, what we are protecting against such as malware-virus-virus hoax-unwanted software installations, what is UAC, windows firewall use, WSUS, SCCM, and general Windows update.
episodes.title: Client Protection

episodes.description: Mike and Zach continue the iscussion of client protection covering update classification, fixes for product-specific security-related vulnerability, what is a service pack, encrypting offline files, and what is 'Principle of Least Privilege.
episodes.title: Client Protection Part 2

episodes.description: Mike and Zach discuss understanding email protection, methods of attack such as spam-virus-spoofing-phishing-& pharming, using smartscreen filter, client vs. server protection, difference between 'client' & 'server' protection, what SPF records are, DNS, and what PTR records are.
episodes.title: Email Protection

episodes.description: Mike and Zach cover server protection fundamentals discussing what we need to understand about areas to consider-location-secure area-seperate subnet/VLAN & RODC, not running all services on one server-separation of services, what is 'hardening,' best practices security guidelines, using updates-patches-disabling unnecessary services, using host based firewall, keeping servers updated, secure Dynamic Domain Name System (DNS), what PAP is, what FTP is, and are all authentication protocols the same.
episodes.title: Server Protection
